noun.description: Approval, support, or liking for someone or something.
examples: the legislation is viewed with favor

noun.description: An act of kindness beyond what is due or usual.
examples: I've come to ask you a favor

verb.description: Feel or show approval or preference for.
examples: slashing public spending is a policy that few politicians favor

verb.description: (often used in polite requests) give someone (something that they want)
examples: please favor me with an answer

verb.description: Resemble (a parent or other relative) in facial features.
examples: she's pretty, and she favors you

verb.description: Treat (an injured limb) gently, not putting one's full weight on it.

phrases: You could of course say he was doing them a favour, what with royalties and all.
They act like they're perfect and they're doing you a favour by even talking to you.
They are actually doing me a favour by striking me off their list.
Adam accepted, although, in retrospect, he rather gave the impression that it was he who was doing me a favour.
Any readers who can suggest suitable reading matter or anything else to keep him amused would be doing me a favour.
origin: Middle English (in the noun sense liking, preference): via Old French from Latin favor, from favere show kindness to (related to fovere cherish).
